content: The text chunk discusses the authority to agree to certain amendments to the Border Environment Cooperation Agreement. The President may agree to amendments to the Cooperation Agreement allowing the Bank to provide grants and loans from its capital resources. The definition of 'border region' would be expanded to include areas within 100 kilometers of the US-Mexico boundary in the US and 300 kilometers in Mexico. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the public law. The Secretary of the Treasury must annually report to the House Committee on Financial Services and the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on the North American Development Bank's approved projects, including details on loans, grants, and project locations near the US-Mexico border. The annual report to Congress on the North American Development Bank includes details on approved projects, certified projects not yet financed, capital amounts, efforts to expand project types, and discussions to improve the bank's effectiveness. The Congress supports NADBank projects financing water conservation for Texas irrigators and agricultural producers in the Lower Rio Grande River Valley. The Congress finds that Texas irrigators are facing hardships due to Mexico's failure to abide by the 1944 Water Treaty, resulting in a significant water debt. Studies show that water savings can be achieved through irrigation system improvements. The North American Development Bank has created a Water Conservation Investment Fund. The Water Conservation Investment Fund of the North American Development Bank will provide up to $80,000,000 for water conservation projects, split equally between the United States and Mexico. Despite efforts in water conservation, irrigated agriculture still consumes over 60% of surface and ground water. The Southwest faces the most inadequate water supplies in the country, with significant water loss in the lower Colorado River basin and Great Plains River basins.
